question: Question_B_02
statement:
Consider the function

\[f(x) = \frac{x}{x^2+1}\]

defined on the whole real line.

The zeros of $\ f'$, increasing order, are \emph{c\textsubscript{1}} =
\_\_\_ and \emph{c\textsubscript{2}} = \_\_\_.

The zeros of $\ f''$, in increasing order, are
\emph{r\textsubscript{1}} = \_\_\_, \emph{r\textsubscript{2}} = \_\_\_
and \emph{r\textsubscript{3}} = \_\_\_.

In each empty cell of the tables below, enter a + or - to indicate sign
of $\ f$, $\ f'$ and $\ f''$ as appropriate.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llll@{}}
& $(-\infty,0)$ & 0 & $(0,\infty)$\\
$\ f(x)$ & & 0 &\\
\end{longtable}

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllll@{}}
& $(-\infty,c_1)$ & \emph{c\textsubscript{1}} &
$\displaystyle (c_1,c_2)$ & \emph{c\textsubscript{2}} & $(c_2,\infty)$\\
$\ f'(x)$ & & 0 & & 0 &\\
\end{longtable}

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llllllll@{}}
& $(-\infty,r_1)$ & \emph{r\textsubscript{1}} &
$\displaystyle (r_1,r_2)$ & \emph{r\textsubscript{2}} &
$\displaystyle (r_2,r_3)$ & \emph{r\textsubscript{3}} & $(r_3,\infty)$\\
$\ f''(x)$ & & 0 & & 0 & & 0 &\\
\end{longtable}
hints:
Calculate the first and second derivatives of $f(x)$ and set them equal
to zero to find the critical points.

To fill in the rest of the tables, for each cell choose a point in the
appropriate interval (which will partially be determined by the critical
points you've already found). Plug it into the appropriate
function/derivative to determine whether it is positive or negative.
Save yourself some work - you don't need to find the exact value, just
whether it is positive or negative.
